articles.headline: Trump’s Order on Social Media Could Harm One Person in Particular: Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Without certain liability protections, companies like Twitter would have to be more aggressive about policing messages that press the boundaries — like the president’s.
articles.abstract: Without certain liability protections, companies like Twitter would have to be more aggressive about policing messages that press the boundaries — like the president’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, who built his political career on the power of a flame-throwing Twitter account, has now gone to war with Twitter, angered that it would presume to fact-check his messages. But the punishment he is threatening could force social media companies to crack down even more on customers just like Mr. Trump.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Bank Regulator’s Battle With Anti-Redlining Law Comes to an End
articles.snippet: Joseph Otting, the top overseer of the country’s largest banks, drew from his own experiences as a banker to rewrite rules for the Community Reinvestment Act. Not everyone is on board.
articles.abstract: Joseph Otting, the top overseer of the country’s largest banks, drew from his own experiences as a banker to rewrite rules for the Community Reinvestment Act. Not everyone is on board.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph Otting came into his job overseeing the nation’s biggest banks in late 2017 determined to rewrite the rules governing how financial institutions invest in poor communities.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Millions Relying on Pandemic Aid Can See Its End, and They’re Scared
articles.snippet: Emergency programs have cushioned the shutdown’s impact on workers and businesses and lifted the economy, but may not outlast the coronavirus crisis.
articles.abstract: Emergency programs have cushioned the shutdown’s impact on workers and businesses and lifted the economy, but may not outlast the coronavirus crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: For millions of Americans left out of work by the coronavirus pandemic, government assistance has been a lifeline preventing a plunge into poverty, hunger and financial ruin.

articles.headline: National Guard Called as Minneapolis Erupts in Solidarity for George Floyd
articles.snippet: Violence in the streets prompted officials to call in troops and vow a swift federal review of the arrest.
articles.abstract: Violence in the streets prompted officials to call in troops and vow a swift federal review of the arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Minnesota’s governor activated the National Guard on Thursday as angry demonstrators took to the streets for a third straight night to protest the death of George Floyd, a black man who was pleading that he could not breathe as a white police officer pressed his knee into Mr. Floyd’s neck.
articles.byline: By Matt Furber, John Eligon and Audra D. S. Burch

articles.headline: Border Wall Land Grabs Accelerate as Owners Shelter From Pandemic
articles.snippet: With private property proving hard to acquire, the administration has stepped up efforts to secure land on the Mexican border for President Trump’s wall.
articles.abstract: With private property proving hard to acquire, the administration has stepped up efforts to secure land on the Mexican border for President Trump’s wall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is accelerating efforts to seize private property for President Trump’s border wall, taking advantage of the coronavirus pandemic to survey land while its owners are confined indoors, residents along the Rio Grande say.

articles.headline: The President Versus the Mods
articles.snippet: President Trump’s taking aim at Twitter for fact-checking his tweets is part of a long tradition upheld by aggrieved internet trolls. The stakes are high.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s taking aim at Twitter for fact-checking his tweets is part of a long tradition upheld by aggrieved internet trolls. The stakes are high.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a teen in the early 2000s, I spent a lot of time on online message boards. They were funny, chaotic places where my fellow nerds and I spent hours arguing about everything under the sun: sports, music, video games, the latest episode of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.”

articles.headline: Google Rescinds Offers to Thousands of Contract Workers
articles.snippet: The company made the cost-cutting move as it navigates a slump in advertising created by the pandemic.
articles.abstract: The company made the cost-cutting move as it navigates a slump in advertising created by the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google, facing an advertising slump caused by the pandemic, has rescinded offers to several thousand people who had agreed to work at the company as temporary and contract workers.

articles.headline: Trump’s Looting and ‘Shooting’ Remarks Escalate Crisis in Minneapolis
articles.snippet: The president’s tweets prompted Twitter to append them with a note saying the posts were “glorifying violence.” Joe Biden condemned Mr. Trump, saying “it’s no time to encourage violence.”
articles.abstract: The president’s tweets prompted Twitter to append them with a note saying the posts were “glorifying violence.” Joe Biden condemned Mr. Trump, saying “it’s no time to encourage violence.”
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump issued a violent ultimatum to protesters in Minneapolis on Friday and inserted himself in a harshly divisive fashion into the crisis there, attacking the city’s Democratic mayor and raising the specter that the military could use armed force to suppress riots that erupted after the death of George Floyd, a black man, at the hands of a white police officer.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Alexander Burns
